story:
As both staff and students of Manchester Dental Hospital, we have been hugely saddened to hear of the passing of our esteemed friend, colleague and tutor, Dr Paul McDonald. 

Paul was a very well - respected member of both our Restorative Dentistry and Oral Surgery teams. Many have had the pleasure of working alongside him at the hospital since 2012 and he has truly had a great impact on many. Paul was well known for his warmth, caring nature and his support for patients, colleagues and students; he will be sadly missed by everyone who knew and worked with him.

In Paul's memory, we will be raising funds for MacMillans Cancer Support. After the passing of Dr McDonalds wife earlier in 2020, we felt that it would be an appropriate way to make a difference in Paul's honour and is a cause especially close to his heart.

Thank you for taking the time to visit this JustGiving page - any donations are hugely appreciated. 

.

story:
After a long battle against her cancer, Donna sadly passed away on 4th December 2020.

She was first diagnosed with endometrial cancer in 2014. Her initial prognosis was poor, between 6-18 months to live. But with her positive attitude and through sheer determination she fought courageously, enduring three major operations and numerous cycles of chemotherapy over the next six years.  

Now she is in a better place, free of pain and suffering. We all miss her dearly and she will be forever in our hearts.

Finally, thank you for joining me in being a part of this.

story:
Hello everyone,

Most of you will know that my father sadly passed away after a long battle with dementia. He is greatly missed and will be forever in our hearts. 

Many of you may not know that before his diagnosis of dementia, he underwent surgery and had a quadruple bypass. This surgery was an amazing success and gave him more years than was ever expected. The care he received and the work that the British Heart foundation did gave us many more happy memories of our father.

In his memory, our family is asking for a donation to help the British Heart Foundation to continue their work and help gives others the chance to spend more time with their loved ones. 

Anything you can donate would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you

story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

eventName: A Christmassy Cardiff Half for Cancer Research
story:
It’s Christmas…so why the heck am I doing this??...

OK, so I’ll tell you why…

Let me take you back to Christmas 1994. I’m 17, and it’s the toughest Christmas I’ve had. There’s an empty space at the table where Mum should be. Just a few months earlier, the cancer had returned, suddenly and brutally, and taken her away. Ten years earlier, when she was 40, she had fought and “beaten” breast cancer…only for it to return, savagely, a decade later.

Looking back, I’m so grateful that research developed the drugs that allowed me to get to know my mother. The difference between losing a parent aged 7 and 17 is immense. More recently, I have another significant reason to be grateful to Cancer Research UK, as they generously fund life saving research in my lab, as we look to develop medicines of the future and stop more families losing loved ones before their time.

This year, many more people will have spaces at the table, where a loved one should be. Many of these spaces are directly due to cancer, many directly due to COVID-19, many cancer deaths may be indirectly related to the pandemic, as patients needed to stop treatment prematurely. Whichever way you look at it, directly or indirectly, the coronavirus pandemic has cost a huge number lives. Looking forwards, the huge hit that charities have taken to their income resulting from the pandemic has meant that world class, life saving science has gone unfunded, or with reduced budgets*, meaning more lives may be lost moving forwards as an indirect result of the pandemic. At Christmas time, let’s try and remember those charities that have been hugely impacted, if you possibly can.

So, that’s why this Christmas Eve, I shall be teaming up with old pal and Media Volunteer Liaison Manager at Cancer Research UK, Tom Bourton, to each run a half marathon to raise funds for Cancer Research UK. “Why a half marathon each?” I hear you cry. Truth be told, I’m certain my knackered hip and bad back won’t manage a full 26.2 miles. Tom is younger and fitter that me and does marathons in his sleep but tells me something about a bad knee - but I’m not sure I believe him! Perhaps between us we make a fully functioning human! Mainly though, it’s symbolic. By running a half marathon each, representing the researcher and the fundraiser, it feels as though we are demonstrating how we are working side-by-side (metaphorically, of course, in an age of social distancing) to reach a common goal. On Christmas Eve, that common goal will running 26.2 miles, raising as much money as possible along the way. By doing so we might just help inch our way towards the real goal…to beat cancer sooner.

So, if you might have sent me a card, or bought me a pint over Christmas, please don’t – but if you can spare that quid or two towards this challenge, I’d be hugely grateful!

*In May 2020, we set up the #Baton4Cancer initiative so that researchers across Wales could help raise much needed funds for the charities which generously fund our research. To read more about this initiative, please see https://www.walescancerresearchcentre.org/pass-the-baton-for-cancer/

story:
Hi everyone.

8 years ago, I decided that it would be a nice idea to make sure everyone had a moment to spend time thinking of friends and loved ones that were not with them on Christmas day, as I was out of the country.

I started out with invites going to close friends, and a couple of years ago - due to people sharing the event - it reached over 123,000 people which was totally amazing, humbling and made me very proud to know that people across so many countries wanted to share a moment together.

I wanted to do the same thing again this year so here it is. A Drink With Friends 2020.

This is especially important in a year that - I think we can all agree - has been a bit rubbish.

Just like last year, as the clock strikes 7pm GMT on Christmas day, wherever we are - traveling, at home, at the pub, (unlikely this year) everyone grabs a drink (doesn't have to be alcoholic) and makes a toast to all the friends and family that have made a difference in our lives.

Following the success of this in previous years, please forward the invitation onto friends and family that you would like to be involved. The more people, the more this will mean - certainly to me.

It would brilliant if we could have something to say as the clock strikes 7pm... So I was thinking something simple like:
"Wherever I am, I'll be with friends and loved ones. Here's to you all and what you mean to me"

Hopefully it's not too cheesy, and puts in a sentence what I wanted this to be about.

I never expected so many to be involved with this event over the years, and to some it has become a tradition! It still shocks me every time I look at the totals of shares that happened each year and the number of people who 'attended'. So much so, that I have re-opened my JustGiving page in case some of you would like to help me to raise a little cash again for a good cause.

In 2008, I lost my mum to cancer, so I thought it would be an awesome idea to give you all an opportunity to donate a little something to Cancer Research UK, however small. I’ve set up https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising-edit/drinkwithfriends2020 for us to use. I’m not expecting any of you to donate – it’s a tough time of year even without the economy being in the state that it is in, but if you feel generous and capable, please give whatever you can.

I'm targeting £1,000 in total, but thanks to previous years, we have already raised more than £1,400 (which is AMAZING 🙂 🙂 🙂 )
If you don’t want to donate, then it’s no problem – I still look forward to sharing a moment with you on Christmas day, and hope to see all the awesome photos that will be shared!

I hope you'll join me in this small gesture - it wont change the world, but it is important to stay connected even if it is by a mutual act, one that stretches across borders and time zones.

Of course if anyone wants to upload pictures of themselves raising their glass - I'll certainly welcome it.

Let's make this Christmas another one to remember.

Thanks for being involved!
Peace,

story:
Our Solihull Hospice has been caring for local people since 1965.

Its a warm and welcoming place where we give expert care to people with a terminal illness, and their loved ones, every day of the year. 

Our hospice team includes doctors, nurses, physiotherapists, social workers and many more, and is supported by over 200 volunteers  who play a vital role in the running of the hospice.

We have a 24-bed in-patient unit, where relatives and friends can visit any time of the day or night, and stay with their loved ones if they wish.

Our out-patient unit offers clinics, therapies and group sessions  and freshly cooked lunches made by our chefs. We also support carers and families, including children, with practical advice, counselling and bereavement support groups.

We need to raise £9,600 per day to run the hospice, so every penny counts. Thank you for helping to make sure more people with a terminal illness in Solihull get the care and support they need.

story:
Geoff was educated at Alloa Academy, and read Astronomy at St Andrew's before gaining a teaching diploma at Glasgow University. Despite these qualifications he has pursued a career in market research. His interest in military history began as a pastime but
rapidly developed into a passion. The Great War became his specialist area and in the 1980s he began an evening degree at North London Polytechnic. The activities of the Kensington Battalion caught his imagination and this book is the result.

He has published a number of social history articles and short stories
and co-edited with Gary Sheffield the letters of Christopher Stone (From Vimy Ridge to the Rhine: The Great War Letters of Major Christopher Stone DSO MC, Crowood, 1989).

Thoughts about
Geoff from some of his many work friends and colleagues…..

Geoff was an absolutely lovely and supportive person, a selfless and humble soul, wonderfully funny and quirky and gifted with exceptional data sciences skills.                                                            

Geoff was a real character and a lovely person. The sort of
person you always remember very fondly.                                                                                                                  

How he had a very different way of working, recalling a past email                      

“I have been a Kantar/BMRB/Mass-Observation (all part
of the group) employee continuously since 1978, now with Kantar Media. I have
been an SPSS user, software provided by the company, since SPSS first made SPSS
PC+ and SPSS-for-Windows back in 1994. Since ~1997 I have had a home licence as
well as an office licence. Almost all of my work is carried out using the home
licence, because I buy and maintain my own computers, much faster than the standard
issue.”

I loved working with Geoff and have numerous fond and funny
memories of him, including memorable matches at Ealing squash club and his
publication of a book on military history (maybe 10 years ago now?). Such a lovely and interesting man, he really lived a full life.               

Every time I stopped off at Geoff’s desk he would have a new discovery to tell me
about. An amazingly talented but very modest man.                                                      

Geoff was
one of those rare people who was modest and effective.                    

I first met Geoff just prior to my joining BMRB in 1986 at
the Summer Party and we spent a large part of the evening together discussing cricket and whisky. Over the years we had many epic battles on the squash
court. Most recently during the interminable office moves I somehow ended up
with a very large framed photo of Everest by my desk, taken by Geoff during his trek. After much persuasion he did finally find a home for it. Fios dhut Geoff, I shall open a fresh Single Malt this evening and have a couple of glasses with
you.                                                                                    

I got to know Geoff quite well when he was part of our DWA
group (along with several others copied). An excellent guy. Here are a couple
of photos of Geoff with the group from one of those gatherings ...                                                                                                               

I remember him well from DWA days and from all his support
on anything statistical - fond memories of a cheeky grin! 

Geoff had a wonderful sense of humour, a great disposition and such talent. I always felt our projects were in good hands when Geoff was managing them.   I will miss Geoff and all the great conversations about data or about his world trips.                                         

Like others I have many good memories of working with Geoff
over many years, going right back to Mass Obs days. He was a clever and amusing person and a joy to work with.

In terms of brain power (and accent) Geoff was definitely on a different planet to me. But he is memorable for his modesty and sheer niceness. I remember having lunch with him in various 'Wine Bars' and eating places in the Ealing offices (he always seemed to eat at different times to everyone else) and I spent many a time understanding only the occasional word but enjoying every minute.

Definitely one of the Good Guys - and a relentless squash player!           

I also loved working with Geoff. He would start by listening attentively. Then he would say, yep yep yep, nodding furiously the while, with his brain ticking.  He was always so incredibly happy to help, so positive, so buoyant and jolly and enthusiastic and CLEVER! Kept me going quite a few times on those cluster analysis conundrums we researchers found ourselves faced with. It was a privilege to have known Geoff.                                                                                                 

I can only echo what so many people have already said. @Kathy, it was also “aye mate” when discussing things. Like all good technical people when explaining things to me, he was incredibly patient and understanding😊 TBH and without wishing to flatter other statisticians on this chain, Kantar/BMRB was truly blessed with some outstanding stats/data science talent!

I didn't know Geoff very well but have loved hearing all the anecdotes. DWA was responsible for building some amazing relationships that have stood the test of time!                

I enjoyed working with Geoff. He always made things
easy to understand, in between his delightful tales of trips to base camp. As others have mentioned, he was a very positive person.

I didn't work with Geoff a lot however on the brief occasions, he was always amazing!

Geoff was wonderful, always so cheerful and so generous with his time. He really helped me understand stats techniques better (well, a bit better!) and played a big part in the success of our team (with P&G in particular, I remember) at a formative time. He used to arrive in the office "for the night shift" in the late afternoon dressed all in black like a stato ninja. RIP Geoff. 

I remember Geoff to be very nice, calm and helpful...

I remember the days when he was asking for different global databases and the email always came through late evening. I
used to think he was based in a different time zone before realising he was actually based in the UK. He was very kind, polite and helpful when I had stats questions. 

I too remember Geoff in the best of lights – as an incredibly warm and friendly man, always happy to have a chat and share some insightful advice. His loss will be keenly felt by all who knew him, myself not least of all.

I was fortunate to work with him on a couple of projects (T-Mobile
segmentation springs to mind, if memory serves me correctly), and as you rightly say he was very gifted but also just a fundamentally decent man, with a great sense of humour.  I know he was Scottish but we never really talked about our shared heritage, other than the fact he really supported the Scotland women’s football team, this was well
before women’s football was more widely highlighted in the media as it is nowadays, which is why I remember.  I know he was a keen mountaineer for some time too and had trips to far flung places including Nepal.  I recall his disappointment on one such trip where he was taken ill early on and had to abandon his plans for scaling at least part of Kathmandu I think, but as ever when recounting the story to me on his return he was able to look on the bright
side and find reasons to be thankful. 
RIP.   

I remember the first email I received from Geoff. It was more like a
letter rather than an email. I spent 40 minutes to ‘decode’ his email. It was the time when I just started my first job in London and I thought there must be something I’m missing on his email as my understanding on statistics and my work was very limited. Later on, I realised that his email wasn’t full of statistical jargons but it was full of his warmth and humour. He helped me so much when I first joined the company, guiding me not to feel lost. He was a very special person with an incredible humour, a warm and down to earth heart,
and a brilliant talent. I will always remember his kindness.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am completing my Bronze Duke of Edinburgh award this year. For my volunteering section, I have chosen to raise funds for Oxfam.

The Duke of Edinburgh award is an award for young people which assesses you on your ability to learn new skills, help people out (both in your community and globally) and get lost in a muddy field after failing to read a map. It's a great way to learn new things and meet new people, while having fun in the process. With the sudden arrival of COVID-19, everyone has had to find new ways to complete their awards - a process which has been both fun and challenging.

I have set up this page to collect funds for a variety of activities, which at the time of writing consists of putting begging notes into an extreme amount of Christmas cards, but will extend to other things, possibly exclusive video content and maybe some artwork. Whichever thing you are donating for, I sincerely hope it won't ruin your day too much. 

Oxfam doesn't need much introduction. It is an amazing charity that changes the lives of hundreds of people daily, and sells excellent jackets. Breaking the cycle of poverty is a hard but rewarding task, and I'm sure they deserve and appreciate all of your money.

Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia. Together, we will bring clean water to 50,000 people in Ethiopia and thousands more around the world, helping them change their own lives, forever. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk
